Subjective: Dizziness, 3 days duration. Woke up with it. Feels like room spinning, also light-headed. Worse with movement, not constant. Not bad when sitting still. Getting up not too bad, but avoids head movement. Mild nausea, no vomiting. No headache. No hearing issues, no tinnitus. No speech difficulty. No limb weakness, but needs to grab hold/sit down when dizzy. Palpitations, heart racing at times, resolves spontaneously. No syncope, no near-syncope. Recent mild cold. No prolonged bed rest. No smoking, no alcohol, no drugs. Friend had brain tumor with dizziness, fears same. Scared, wants dizziness gone, impacting daily activities. Request: Wants dizziness resolved.
Objective: Vitals: BP 110/70, Pulse 62, regular. Neuro exam: Sensation intact bilaterally face. Cranial nerves intact (eye closure, eyebrow raise, teeth clench, cheek puff, tongue protrusion). Shoulder shrug intact. Arm drift negative with eyes closed. Finger-to-nose intact bilaterally. Leg strength intact (knee flexion/extension, heel to buttock). Gait normal, tandem gait normal. No nystagmus on smooth pursuit. HIT test negative bilaterally. Dix-Hallpike positive on right (provoked vertigo, nausea, observed nystagmus), less intense on left.
Assessment: Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo (BPPV), right > left. Dizziness secondary to displaced otoconia in posterior semicircular canal. No evidence of central pathology (e.g., brain tumor) given negative neurological exam and Dix-Hallpike findings.
Plan:
1. Reassurance regarding benign nature of BPPV, not indicative of tumor.
2. Epley maneuver performed in office today.
3. Instructions for home exercises via thuisarts.nl.
4. Advised to avoid provoking movements initially, gradually increase head movement as tolerated.
5. Safety netting: Return if symptoms worsen significantly, new neurological deficits (weakness, numbness, vision changes, severe headache), or persistent vomiting.
6. Follow-up: As needed.
